{{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = Rtd. [[General officer|General]] | name = Solomon Mujuru | image = Solomon Mujuru.jpg | imagesize = 230px | birth_name = Solomon Mutusva | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1945|5|5}} | birth_place = [[Chivhu|Enkeldoorn]], [[Southern Rhodesia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2011|8|15|1945|5|5}} | death_place = [[Alamein Farm]], [[Beatrice, Zimbabwe]] | resting_place = [[National Heroes Acre (Zimbabwe)|National Heroes Acre]] | nationality = [[Zimbabwean]] | party = [[ZANU-PF]] | residence = Alamein Farm | spouse = [[Joice Mujuru]] | occupation = Military leader, Politician |office = Second Gentlemen of Zimbabwe |term_start = 6 December 2004 |term_end = 15 August 2011 |president = [[Robert Mugabe]] |predecessor = [[Simon Muzenda|Maud Muzenda]] |successor = [[Auxillia Mnangagwa]] |office1 = Commander of the [[Zimbabwe Defence Forces]] |term_start1 = 1981 |term_end1 = 1992 |president1 = [[Robert Mugabe]] |predecessor1 = [[Peter Walls]] |successor1 = [[Vitalis Zvinavashe]] |nickname = Rex Nhongo |allegiance = {{flagicon|Zimbabwe}} [[Zimbabwe]] |branch = [[Zimbabwe National Army]]
[[Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army]] |serviceyears = 1964–1990 |rank = [[General officer|General]] |unit = |commands = |battles = [[Rhodesian Bush War]] |awards = }} '''Solomon Mujuru''' (born '''Solomon Mutusva'''; 5 May 1945 – 15 August 2011), also known by his [[nom-de-guerre]], '''Rex Nhongo''', was a [[Zimbabwe]]an military officer and politician who led [[Robert Mugabe]]'s guerrilla forces during the [[Rhodesian Bush War]]. He was from the [[Zezuru]] clan. In post-independence Zimbabwe, he went on to become army chief before leaving government service in 1995. After leaving his post in the Zimbabwe National Army, he got into politics becoming Member of Parliament for Chikomba on a Zanu PF ticket. He was generally regarded as one of the most feared men in Zimbabwe. His wife, [[Joice Mujuru]], became Vice-President of Zimbabwe in 2004. ==Biography== ===Early life=== {{unreferenced section|date=July 2016}} Born Solomon Mutusva in [[Chivhu|Enkeldoorn]], [[Southern Rhodesia]], Mujuru took an interest in politics at an early age. He was first arrested for his activism while a student at [[Zimuto High School (Zimbabwe)|Zimuto High School]] and later joined the youth league of the [[Zimbabwe African People's Union]] (ZANU). He was detained again by the Rhodesian authorities in 1966 and sentenced to two years' imprisonment. Upon his release, Mujuru fled to [[Lusaka]], [[Zambia]], where he was recruited for guerrilla training in the [[Soviet Union]]. ===Rhodesian Bush War=== During the [[Zimbabwe War of Liberation]] Mujuru, with [[Josiah Tongogara]], led the [[Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army]] (ZANLA) while [[Robert Mugabe]] was in jail for 10 years (from 1964 to 1974). Mugabe, along with [[Edgar Tekere]], subsequently slipped into [[Mozambique]] after their release, with assistance from chief [[Rekayi Tangwena]], where Mujuru petitioned the insurgents to accept Mugabe as their leader.{{cite news|url=http://www.sundaytribune.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=2367172%3Cp%3E |title=It is universally accepted in Zanu-PF that without Solomon's active support, Mugabe would have been a nobody. Solomon and the late Josiah Tongogara led the Zanla forces|newspaper= Sunday Tribune|date= 9 January 2005}} In 1976, Mujuru was appointed military chief of the [[Patriotic Front (Zimbabwe)|Patriotic Front]], a theoretical amalgamation of ZAPU and Mugabe's [[Zimbabwe African National Union]] (ZANU). From 1976 to 1979, he supervised operational planning, infiltration, and the movement of ZANLA cadres inside Rhodesia. In 1980, the ZANLA commander was instrumental in demobilising former guerrillas in assembly points monitored by Commonwealth forces. {{citation needed|date=July 2016}} ===Post-Independence=== Promoted to general in the new [[Zimbabwe National Army]], Mujuru oversaw ZANLA's integration into the [[Zimbabwe Defence Forces]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Solomon-Mujuru|title=Solomon Mujuru {{!}} Zimbabwean military leader and businessman|newspaper=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-02-13|language=en}} He was appointed chief of the army following the resignation of Lieutenant-General [[Peter Walls]], and retired in 1992 to go into business.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/11/solomon-mujuru-obituary |title=Solomon Mujuru obituary |last=Chan |first=Stephen |date=11 September 2011 |newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=13 February 2017 |language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} As a civilian, he became influential in the [[Zimbabwe National Liberation War Veterans Association]], lobbying for increased veterans' welfare and a prominent stake in the [[Land reform in Zimbabwe|land reform programme]].{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} ==Politics== It was generally thought that Mujuru had a tremendous amount of influence on who would lead ZANU-PF and the country. He was the only person believed to have had the stature to challenge Mr Mugabe during party meetings. Newspaper reports claimed Mujuru had been under house arrest and 24-hour surveillance between 2007 and 2008 for his role in attempting to oust Mugabe.{{cite news|url=http://www.thezimbabwean.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=11182:Mujuru%20under%20house%20arrest&catid=31:top%20zimbabwe%20stories&Itemid=66 |title= Mujuru under house arrest|newspaper=The Zimbabwean|date= 18 February 2008}}{{cite news |url=http://www.thezimbabwean.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=11182:Mujuru%20under%20house%20arrest&catid=31:top%20zimbabwe%20stories&Itemid=66 |title=Senior figures from within the party led by former army chief Solomon Mujuru are expected to challenge Mr Mugabe|newspaper=The Zimbabwean |date= 18 February 2008}} However, he remained an influential member of the ruling [[ZANU-PF]] politburo and central committees. Mujuru and his wife were among the [[ZANU-PF]] party members subject to personal [[International sanctions|sanctions]] imposed by the United States. ==Business and Black Economic Empowerment== Mujuru was a successful businessman and commercial farmer, who both advocated and benefitted from indigenisation and [[black economic empowerment]] in Zimbabwe. He had diverse business ventures,{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14550942|title=Solomon Mujuru: Obituary of a Zimbabwean 'king-maker'|date=16 August 2011 |accessdate=10 December 2013|work=BBC}} which included mining, agriculture, transport, tourism and investment in the construction industry. In the mid-1990s Mujuru clashed with [[Emmerson Mnangagwa]], long considered Mugabe's favoured heir, when Solomon bid to buy into the multibillion-dollar [[Zimasco]], a chrome mining and smelting concern in Zimbabwe's Midlands Province.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6507993.stm|title=Profile: The Mujuru couple|date=24 February 2009|accessdate=12 October 2013|work=BBC}} == Farming == Popular speculation is that Mujuru owned anywhere between six and sixteen farms,{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} including Alamein Farm, seized from Guy Watson-Smith during the [[Land reform in Zimbabwe#Fast-track Land Reform and violence|fast-track land reform]] in 2001.{{cite news|url= http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-3319957-we-were-given-minutes-to-leave.do|title= Farm owner given minutes to leave his Farm|newspaper= The London Evening Standard|date= 10 February 2003|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110805144548/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-3319957-we-were-given-minutes-to-leave.do|archivedate= 5 August 2011|df= dmy-all}} His seizure of Alamein Farm was at the time ruled illegal by the [[Supreme Court of Zimbabwe]].{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/zimbabwe/1366242/Evicted-farmer-sues-for-return-of-2m-assets.html |title= Evicted farmer sues for return of £2m assets|newspaper= The Telegraph|date= 24 December 2001}}{{cite news|url= http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-541448-britain-must-act-on-zimbabwe.do|title= Britain must act on Zimbabwe|newspaper= The London Evening Standard|date= 25 January 2002|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20120914142124/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-541448-britain-must-act-on-zimbabwe.do|archivedate= 14 September 2012|df= dmy-all}} Mujuru farmed with tobacco, maize and game at Alamein Farm.{{cite news|url=http://www.zimpapers.co.zw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4969:solomon-mujuru-the-farmer&catid=38:local-news&Itemid=131|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005043712/http://www.zimpapers.co.zw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4969:solomon-mujuru-the-farmer&catid=38:local-news&Itemid=131|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 October 2011|title=Solomon Mujuru the farmer|work=The Sunday Mail|date=21 August 2011|accessdate=2011-08-23}} Farm workers also produced their own tobacco on land allocated to them.{{cite news|url=http://www.zbc.co.zw/news-categories/top-stories/11183-mujuru-condolences-ocme-in.html|title=Mujuru condolences pour|publisher=ZBC|date=16 August 2011|accessdate=2011-08-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818144204/http://www.zbc.co.zw/news-categories/top-stories/11183-mujuru-condolences-ocme-in.html|archivedate=18 August 2011|df=dmy-all}} == Death == Solomon Mujuru died in a fire in the early hours of the night of 15 August 2011, at the homestead of Alamein Farm,{{cite news |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2011-08-16-zimbabwes-general-solomon-mujuru-dies-in-fire |title=Zimbabwe's General Solomon Mujuru dies in fire|newspaper=Mail and Guardian|location= South Africa|author=Bauer, Nickolaus |date=16 August 2011}} in circumstances that many commentators suggest were suspicious.{{cite news |url=http://www.thoughtleader.co.za/jeremiahkure/2011/08/21/of-securocrats-candles-and-a-raging-dictatorship/|title=Securocrats, Candles and a raging dictatorship|publisher=''Mail & Guardian, South Africa''}}{{cite news |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/africa/2011/08/21/mujuru-death-no-accident|title=Mujuru death no accident|publisher=''The Times, South Africa''}} He had stopped at the Beatrice Hotel, 60 km south-west of Harare, where he had drunk and chatted with patrons; he was having an early night before a long journey the next day. A maid and guard at the farm testified they heard gunshots two hours before flames were seen at his farmhouse. Mujuru had left groceries and his cell phone in his car, something he had never done before. The general had taken 40 minutes to drive from the hotel to his farm, a journey of 10 minutes.{{cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2012-02-06-zim-generals-death-shrouded-in-suspicion/ |title=Doubts raised about Mujuru's cause of death|newspaper=Mail and Guardian |location= South Africa |date=6 February 2012}} The lone policeman was asleep at the time, and after he awoke, he had no airtime, and the radio was broken. When the firetruck arrived it had no water.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16602768 |title=Zimbabwe policeman 'slept during Solomon Mujuru fire|work=BBC|date=17 January 2012 |location=Africa}} An enquiry was opened. The coroner investigating Mujuru's death concluded he had died of smoke inhalation, but Mujuru's family lacks confidence in the coroner's findings. They plan to petition for approval to exhume Mujuru's remains and have them independently examined by a doctor of their own choice. Mujuru's remains are located at [[National Heroes Acre (Zimbabwe)|Heroes Acre]], a memorial in Zimbabwe.{{cite news|last=Gonda|first=Violet|title=Zimbabwe Court Rules Smoke Inhalation Killed Mujuru, Family Demands Exhumation|url=http://www.voanews.com/zimbabwe/news/Zimbabwean-Coroner-Rules-Smoke-Inhalation-killed-Mujuru-Family-Call-for-Exhumation-142961325.html|accessdate=16 March 2012|newspaper=Voice of America|date=16 March 2012|author2=Thomas Chiripasi}} == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mujuru, Solomon}} [[Category:Zimbabwean generals]] [[Category:Zimbabwean politicians]] [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army personnel]] [[Category:ZANU–PF politicians]] [[Category:Deaths from fire]]

[[File:Theodore Fischer auctioning Georges Braque's Stilleben (1924) in 1939.jpg|thumbnail|Theodore Fischer auctioning [[Georges Braque]]'s ''Stilleben'' (''Still Life'') (1924) in 1939]] [[File:Galerie Fischer 1939 auction catalogue.jpg|thumbnail|The catalogue for the 1939 sale at the Grand Hotel]] [[File:Grazing Horses IV, Three Red Horses, Franz Marc, 1911.jpg|thumbnail|[[Franz Marc]], ''Grazing Horses IV'', or ''Three Red Horses'', 1911. One of the pictures sold by Fischer at the 1939 Grand Hotel auction.<ref>[http://plundered-art.blogspot.co.uk/2012/01/red-horses-by-franz-marc.html "The Red Horses" by Franz Marc.] Marc Masurovsky, ''plundered art'', Holocaust Art Restitution Project, 3 January 2012. Retrieved 16 January 2014.</ref>]] '''Theodor Fischer''' (1878–1957) was a Swiss [[art dealer]] and auctioneer in [[Lucerne]] who after the First World War built a highly successful firm of auctioneers that dominated the Swiss art market. In 1939 he was the auctioneer at the infamous Grand Hotel auction of "[[degenerate art]]" removed from German museums by the [[Nazis]]. During the Second World War he played a key part in the trading of art looted by the Germans from occupied countries.
==Early life== Fischer was born in 1878. In his early career he was associated with the firm of [[Paul Cassirer]] of Berlin, with whom a joint auction was held in 1931 after Cassirer's death. He became a director of the Bosshard Gallery in Lucerne.<ref name=fisch/>
==Between the World Wars== Fischer founded [[Galerie Fischer]] in 1907.<ref name=fisch>[http://www.fischerauktionen.ch/ueber/geschichte.aspx?l=en Portrait.] Fischer. Retrieved 12 January 2014.</ref> He later established a branch of the gallery in Berlin. He built up a large business in Lucerne between the wars and sold a number of important collections. He established his own premises there in 1939 at 17 [[Haldenstrasse]]. Before then auctions were conducted at the [[Zunfthaus zur Meisen|Zur Meisen Guild House]] in Zurich and the [[Grand Hotel National]], Haldenstrasse, in Lucerne.<ref name=fisch/>
==1939 Grand Hotel auction== In 1937 the Nazi party assembled, from art that they had removed from German museums, the [[Degenerate Art Exhibition]], an exhibition of mostly modern art that toured Germany until early 1939. The exhibition was intended to show the deterioration in art brought about by Jewish and [[Bolshevik]] influences. The creation of the exhibition was followed up by a far larger exercise to collect "degenerate art" from throughout Germany. On the instructions of [[Joseph Goebbels]], German Reich Minister of Propaganda, attempts were made to sell some of the more valuable "degenerate" works abroad to raise foreign currency to help the war effort. Dealers were appointed in Germany for this purpose and Theodore Fischer was instructed to hold an auction of "degenerate art" in Switzerland. This took place on 30 June 1939 at the Grand Hotel National.<ref name=Lost>Harclerode, Peter, & Brendan Pittaway. (1999) ''The Lost Masters: The Looting of Europe's Treasurehouses''. London: Victor Gollancz, pp. 4-5. {{ISBN|0575052546}}</ref><ref name=DW>[http://www.dw.de/conspiracies-swirl-in-1939-nazi-art-burning/a-17510022 "Conspiracies swirl in 1939 Nazi art burning."] [[Deutsche Welle]]. Retrieved 26 January 2015.</ref>
Among the 126 pictures offered were [[Franz Marc]]'s ''Three Red Horses'', [[Paul Gauguin]]'s ''Landscape of Tahiti with Three Female Tigers'', [[Pablo Picasso]]'s ''The Harlequins'' and a self-portrait by [[Paul Modersohn]]. In addition, there were four more paintings by Marc, fifteen by [[Lovis Corinth]], nine by [[Carl Hofer]], nine by [[Oskar Kokoschka]], seven by Emil Nolde, five by [[Ernst Barlach]], two by [[Paul Klee]], and three each by [[Max Beckmann]], [[Erich Heckel]], [[Ernst Kirchner]], [[Max Pechstein]] and [[Karl Schmidt-Rottluff]].<ref name=Lost/> Despite the contempt of the Nazis for the "degenerate art" on offer, the auction was described by the Fischer gallery in more flattering terms as a sale of ''Gemalde und Plastiken Moderner Meister aus Deutschen Museen'',<ref>[http://www.lootedart.com/QH3E7U275681 "Research Resources: 'Entartete Kunst' Inventory at the V&A Goes Online 31 January 2014"] lootedart.com. Retrieved 16 January 2015.</ref> (''Paintings and Sculptures of Modern Masters from German Museums'').
The sale was widely publicised and previews were held at Zurich and Lucerne but it did not have the atmosphere of a normal fine art auction. Some people were in the audience only out of curiosity and a number of bidders, who might have been expected to attend, were absent because they were worried the proceeds would be used to prop-up the Nazi regime. Others were bargain-hunters or bought because they feared what would happen to the pictures if they went unsold. [[Marianne Breslauer|Marianne Feilchenfeldt]] and her husband were shocked to discover that one of the canvases for sale was ''Cathedral of Bordeaux'' (1924/25) by [[Oskar Kokoschka]], a painting that they had donated to the [[Nationalgalerie]] in Berlin but which had been deaccessioned in 1937.<ref name=Europa>[[Lynn H. Nicholas|Nicholas, Lynn H.]] (1995) ''[[The Rape of Europa: The Fate of Europe's Treasures in the Third Reich and the Second World War]]''. New York: Vintage Books, pp. 3–5. {{ISBN|9780679756866}}</ref>
Curt Valentin, owner of the Buchholz Gallery in New York, purchased five works at the beheist of [[Alfred H. Barr Jr.]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Marquis|first1=Alice Goldfarb|title=Alfred H. Barr, Jr: Missionary for the Modern|date=1989|publisher=Contemporary Books|location=Chicago|isbn=9780809244041|pages=431|url=http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/925163952|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> The director of the [[Museum Of Modern Art]] "secretly enlisted Valentin as his agent in the Fischer auction, with funds supplied by his trustees".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cohan|first1=William D.|title=MoMA’s Problematic Provenances|url=http://www.artnews.com/2011/11/17/momas-problematic-provenances/|website=Artnews.com|publisher=Art News|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> The paintings were: "Andre Derain's "Valley of the Lot at Vers," stolen from the Cologne Museum; E. L. Kirchner's "Street Scene" and Wilhelm Lehmbruck's "Kneeling Woman," both taken from the Berlin National Gallery; Paul Klee's "Around the Fish," pilfered from the Dresden Gallery, and Henri Matisse's "Blue Window," seized from the Essen Museum."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Marquis|first1=Alice Goldfarb|title=Nazi Art Loot Found Its Way to New York's Modern Museum|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/10/09/opinion/l-nazi-art-loot-found-its-way-to-new-york-s-modern-museum-483346.html|website=Nytimes.com|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref>
Fischer's auctioneering was reported by ''Beaux Arts'' of France to be efficient but the journal couldn't help noting his disdainful attitude to the lots. Of ''Man with a Pipe''<ref>Otherwise known as ''The Smoker''. 1917. Lot 111, unsold. Now lost.</ref> by [[Max Pechstein]] they reported that, "he said with a little sneer, "This must be a portrait of the artist" ... when he withdrew other lots, which he had started at rather a high minimum, he took wicked pleasure in observing loudly, "Nobody wants that sort of thing," or "This lady doesn't please the public" ... and he smiled when he said the word "withdrawn".<ref>"La Vente des oeuvres d'art dégénérés à Lucerne", ''Beaux Arts'', 7 July 1939. Translated by Lynn H. Nicholas. Nicholas, 1995, p. 4.</ref> The prices realised in the sale were below expectations and 28 lots went unsold.<ref name=Europa/>
==Second World War== Many of the established art markets in Europe were closed or restricted during the Second World War, making neutral Switzerland with its borders with Germany, Italy, Austria and France, an attractive alternative to Paris or London as a place to buy or sell art.<ref>[http://www.commartrecovery.org/cases/switzerland Switzerland Neutral Haven And A Willing Wartime Art Market.] Commission for Art Recovery, 2010. Retrieved 13 January 2014.</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110901072348/http://www.ess.uwe.ac.uk/genocide/Switzerland9.htm Switzerland and the Looted Art Trade Linked to World War II.] Georg Kreis, [[University of Basel]], Switzerland. 11 December 1999. Retrieved 26 January 2015 from Internet Archive.</ref>
People were dislocated by the war and some had capital trapped abroad, leading to an urgent need to raise funds. The wife of Jewish collector [[Gisèle Freund|Julius Freund]], for instance, who had been forced to flee Germany, sold part of his collection through Galerie Fischer as she urgently needed to raise funds.<ref>[http://www.lootedart.com/NIF7RH961951 'Nazi-Era Art Claims in the United States:10 years after the Washington Conference'.] lootedart.com. Retrieved 26 January 2015.</ref> The Nazi regime in Germany sold looted art in order to raise foreign currency and collectors and dealers sought to profit from sales forced by wartime exigencies.
Fischer, who already dominated the Swiss market, was able to exploit these conditions to the full, to the extent that in 1946, the USS Office of Strategic Services Art Looting Intelligence Unit (ALIU) described him as "the focal point in all looted art transactions in Switzerland, and recipient of the greatest number of looted paintings located to date".<ref name=loot>"Fischer, Theodor." [http://www.lootedart.com/MVI3RM469661 Post-War Reports: Art Looting Intelligence Unit (ALIU) Reports 1945–1946 and ALIU Red Flag Names List and Index.] lootedart.com Retrieved 12 January 2015.</ref> [[File:Wilhelm Trübner Karl Haberstock.jpg|thumbnail|''Karl Haberstock'' by [[Wilhelm Trübner]], 1914. Haberstock was Adolf Hitler's art agent and a client of Fischer.]]
===Methods=== Fischer used an agent in [[Darmstadt]] named [[Carl Bümming]] to negotiate with [[Adolf Hitler]]'s art agent [[Karl Haberstock]], who like Fischer had worked for Cassirer. In Switzerland, Fischer used the services of Swiss-resident German dealer [[Hans Wendland]] to import large quantities of looted art into the country for onward sale. In November 1942, Wendland received a whole railway wagon full of art from Paris. In 1943 he received a large quantity of art from Italy. According to [[Douglas Cooper (art historian)|Douglas Cooper]], Wendland acted on behalf of Fischer in negotiating with [[Hermann Göring]]'s art agent [[Walter Hofer]], and Wendland and Fischer were partners in most of the transactions. The two had known each other since at least 1931<ref>Some sources say they met in 1920.</ref> when Fischer had bailed Wendland out of some financial difficulties. According to Cooper, the value of trade between Fischer and Hofer for the two years to December 1942 was Swiss Francs 1,133,930. Trade between Hofer and Wendland between 1940 and January 1944 was French Francs 7,420,000 and Swiss Francs 258,000.<ref name=Harc130>Harclerode, pp. 130–132.</ref> Fischer also had close connections with the Zurich galleries Galerie Schmidlin and Galerie Neupert, both of which dealt in looted art.<ref name=Harc130/> The ALIU and [[Bergier commission]] Reports also point to the importance of German refugee art dealers such as [[Fritz Nathan]] who acted as an intermediary between Fischer, Hofer and [[Emil Georg Bührle]].<ref name="loot" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Switzerland, National Socialism and the Second World War Final Report|last=Independent Commission of Experts Switzerland – Second World War Jean-François Bergier, Chairman|first=|publisher=Pendo Verlag GmbH, Zürich|year=2002|isbn=3-85842-603-2|location=https://www.uek.ch/en/schlussbericht/synthesis/ueke.pdf|pages=350–1,360}}</ref>
===Deals with Hermann Göring=== Fischer made several deals with Hermann Göring through his agent Walter Hofer. Göring particularly prized German [[Old Master|old master]] works and in February 1941, Hofer selected seven such from Galerie Fischer which were shipped to Göring's palace at [[Karinhall]]. They included four paintings by the German master [[Lucas Cranach the Elder]], a triptych by a Frankfurt master and a statue of a ''Female Saint Holding a Ring'' (c. 1500) of the Nuremberg school. The Cranach paintings were ''Madonna and Child in a Landscape'', ''Crucifixion with a Knight as Donor'', ''St. Anne and the Virgin'', and ''Portrait of a Bearded Kurfurst''.<ref name=Harc128/><ref name="Alford2012">{{cite book|author=[[Kenneth D. Alford|Alford, Kenneth D.]]|title=Hermann Goring and the Nazi Art Collection: The Looting of Europe's Art Treasures and Their Dispersal After World War II|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6Cvqr_4Zak0C&pg=PA119|year=2012|publisher=McFarland|location=Jefferson|isbn=978-0-7864-8955-8|page=119}}</ref>
Göring originally agreed to pay in Swiss francs but as foreign currency was difficult to obtain, even for him, it was later agreed that Fischer would receive 25 [[French Impressionism|French Impressionist]] paintings instead.<ref>[http://www.lootedart.com/MFEU4S18272 ALIU Detailed Interrogation Report: Hans WENDLAND, 18 September 1946.] lootedart.com. Retrieved 26 January 2015.</ref> Among these were works by [[Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot]], [[Charles Cottet]], [[Edgar Degas]], [[Édouard Manet]], [[Alfred Sisley]], [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir]] and [[Vincent van Gogh]]. All had previously been in the [[Moïse Lévy de Benzion]] and [[Alphonse Kann]] collections,<ref name=Harc128>Harclerode, p. 128.</ref> apart from ''Flowers in a Vase'' (also known as ''Glass with Wild Flowers'') (1890) by van Gogh, which had been part of the [[Alfred Lindon]] collection.<ref name=Harc128>Harclerode, p. 128.</ref><ref name=Yeide447>[[Nancy Yeide|Yeide, Nancy H.]] (2009) ''Beyond the Dreams of Avarice: The Hermann Goering Collection.'' Dallas: Laurel Publishing, pp. 447 & 458 D36. {{ISBN|0977434915}}</ref>
Another looted work handled by Fischer was Degas' ''Madame Camus at the Piano'' (1869). This had been in the Kann collection but seized by the [[Einsatzstab Reichsleiter Rosenberg]] (ERR) in 1941. From there it passed into the Göring collection who exchanged it with [[Gustav Rochlitz]] for older works. From Rochlitz it went to Wendland and from there to Fischer who sold it in 1942 to industrialist [[Emil Georg Bührle|Emil Bührle]]. It was recovered by Kann's heirs in 1948, only to be sold back to Bührle in 1951.<ref name=Yeide458>Yeide, p. 458, D31.</ref>
Other paintings seized by the [[Einsatzstab Reichsleiter Rosenberg|ERR]] for the Göring collection that passed into the hands of Theodor Fischer included: <gallery widths="170px" heights="170px" perrow="4"> File:Entrée d'un gave (Source of a Mountain Stream).jpg|[[Gustave Courbet]], ''Entree d'un Gave'', 1876. Seized from Lévy de Benzion in 1941. Exchanged for old master works from Galerie Fischer in 1941.<ref>[http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/02/monuments_men.html "Monuments Man: Birmingham Museum of Art's founding director Richard Howard helped restitute Nazi-plundered art."] Michael Huebner, AL.com, 7 February 2014. Retrieved 20 January 2015.</ref><ref>Yeide, p. 456, D22.</ref>
File:Van Gogh - Glas mit Feldblumen.jpeg|Vincent van Gogh, ''Flowers in a Vase'', 1890. Seized from Alfred Lindon and exchanged for old master works from Galerie Fischer in 1941.<ref name=Yeide447/>
File:Georges-Pierre Seurat - The Channel at Gravelines, Evening - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Georges Seurat]], ''The Channel at Gravelines/Evening View of a Harbour with Two Sailboats'', 1890. Seized from [[Paul Rosenberg (art dealer)|Paul Rosenberg]] in 1941. To Galerie Fischer in 1942.<ref>Yeide, p. 468, D113.</ref>
File:Edgar Degas, Madame Camus at the Piano, 1869.jpg|Edgar Degas, ''Madame Camus at the Piano'', 1869. Seized from the Alphonse Kann collection 1941. Sold by Fischer to Emil Bührle in 1942.<ref name=Yeide458/> </gallery>
===South American connections=== Among Fischer's other connections was the Catalan politician, [[Francoist]] sympathizer and art collector [[Francesc Cambó]], who dealt almost solely with Fischer. He moved to Buenos Aires shortly after the start of the Second World War. Fischer was also connected with the Austrian dealer [[Thaddeus Grauer]] who moved to Brazil in 1941 via Switzerland.<ref>[http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C13443670 FO 837/1154/5.] The National Archives. Retrieved 29 January 2015.</ref> In 1998, more than 24 paintings looted from European Jews were discovered in a São Paulo art gallery. They were traced to Grauer and before that Fischer.<ref>Harclerode, p. 240.</ref><ref>[http://www.lootedart.com/MFEU4783877 News Reports: 'Brazil uncovers Nazi war loot'] lootedart.com. Retrieved 28 January 2015.</ref> The paintings included a Picasso and a Monet.<ref>[http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/mundo/ft16099804.htm "Arte expropriada tem destino debatido."] Mario Cesar Carvalho, ''Folha De S.Paulo'', 16 September 1998. Retrieved 29 January 2015.</ref>
==Post war== After the end of the Second World War, the descendants and original owners of looted art began to try to recover their property in a process that is still continuing.
Around September 1945, [[Paul Rosenberg (art dealer)|Paul Rosenberg]], whose collection had been plundered by the Nazis, travelled to Switzerland in search of the paintings looted from him. Finding several in the collection of Emil Bührle, he demanded their return. Bührle refused but said he would return them to Theodor Fischer, from whom he had acquired them, as long as he received a full refund from Fischer. Fischer acknowledged that he had acquired them from Hofer and knew them to be looted but claimed that he had been unable to return them.<ref name=Harc136>Harclerode, pp. 136–137.</ref>
The Swiss government was forced to return some looted works of art to their original owners, despite the [[Swiss Syndicate of Art Dealers]] instructing its members not to provide any information on the topic. In the 1950s, Theodor Fischer sued the Swiss government for compensation of over one million Swiss Francs in respect of these restitutions but was awarded only 200,000 francs in settlement.<ref name="Bischol">{{cite book|author1=Bischof, Günter |author2=Anton Pelinka|author3=Ferdinand Karlhofer. (Eds.)|title=The Vranitzky Era in Austria|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gO9BLoCyT-cC&pg=PA237|year=1999|publisher=Transaction Publishers|location=New Brunswick, New Jersey|isbn=978-1-4128-4113-9|page=237}}</ref>
==Death== Fischer died in 1957. His business was taken over by his sons, Arthur (1905–1981) and Paul (1911–1976).<ref name=fisch/>
==Major collections sold by Theodor Fischer== [[File:William Randolph Hearst cph 3a49373.jpg|thumbnail|180px|William Randolph Hearst, for whom Fischer sold arms and armour.]] Note: This list excludes the Second World War era.<ref name=fisch/> *The [[Harrach|Count Harrach]] Collection *The Chillingworth and Wessner Collections (1922) *The Grossherzoglich Sächsische Arms Collection of the [[Grand Duchy of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach|Grand Dukes of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach]] (1927) *The Collection of [[Prince Friedrich Leopold of Prussia]] (1928) *The Rütschi Collection (1931) *The estate of Dr Burger *The Erbach Collection of Arms and Armour (1931) *The [[Von Kleist|Freiherr von Kleist]] Collection *The Collection of Arms and Armour of [[Victor II, Duke of Ratibor|Duke Viktor von Ratibor]] *The [[Thun und Hohenstein|Prince of Thun]] Armoury (1933) *The Arts-and-Crafts Collection of Dr Kodella (1934) *The Hunting Cabinet of [[Reichsgraf von Kaunitz]] *The Bühler Collection (1935) *The [[Randolph Hearst]] Collection of Arms and Armour (1939) *The estate of [[Countess Tiele-Winkler]] (1951)
==Notes and references== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.lootedart.com/MFEU4O35024 Federal Finance Administration (Eidgenössische Finanzverwaltung): Fischer Gallery archives.]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fischer, Theodor}} [[Category:1878 births]] [[Category:1957 deaths]] [[Category:Swiss art dealers]] [[Category:Swiss auctioneers]] [[Category:Art and cultural repatriation after World War II]] [[Category:20th-century Swiss businesspeople]] [[Category:looting]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{about|the bear enthusiast|the American businessman|Timothy Dexter}} {{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=October 2014}} {{cleanup|date=September 2018|reason=Incomplete summary of events from cited sources and poor organization of certain non-sequential information.}} }} {{Infobox person |name = Timothy Treadwell |image = File:Timothy Treadwell.jpg |image_size = 200 |caption = |birth_name = Timothy William Dexter |birth_date = {{birth date|1957|4|29}} |birth_place = [[Long Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2003|10|6|1957|4|29}} |death_place = [[Katmai National Park and Preserve]], [[Alaska]], U.S. |death_cause = Fatal [[bear attack]] |occupation = Environmentalist
Naturalist
Documentary filmmaker |years_active= 1990–2003 |height = |weight = }} '''Timothy Treadwell''' (born '''Timothy William Dexter'''; April 29, 1957 {{ndash}} October 5, 2003) was an American [[Bear#Relationship with humans|bear enthusiast]], [[environmentalist]], [[documentary|documentary filmmaker]], founder of the bear-protection organization Grizzly People. He lived among [[grizzly bear]]s of [[Katmai National Park and Preserve|Katmai National Park]] in [[Alaska]] for 13 summers. At the end of his 13th summer in the park, in 2003, he and his girlfriend Amie Huguenard were killed and almost fully eaten by a 28-year-old [[brown bear]], whose stomach was later found to contain human remains and clothing.{{cite news|last1=Medred|first1=Craig|title=Biologist Believes Errors Led to Timothy Treadwell and Amie Huguenard Attack|url=http://www.wolfsongnews.org/news/Alaska_current_events_1381.htm|accessdate=August 2, 2017|agency=Anchorage Daily News|date=August 28, 2005}} Treadwell's life, work, and death were the subject of [[Werner Herzog]]'s critically acclaimed documentary film ''[[Grizzly Man]]'' (2005).''Grizzly Man'' (DVD). Directed by [[Werner Herzog]]. Lions Gate, 2005. == Early life == Treadwell was born on [[Long Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]], one of five children of Val and Carol Dexter. He attended [[Connetquot High School]], where he achieved B average grades and was the swimming team's star diver. He was very fond of animals and kept a squirrel named Willie as a pet. In an interview in the film ''[[Grizzly Man]]'' (2005), his parents say he was an ordinary young man until he went away to college. There, he claimed that he was a British orphan who was born in [[Australia]]. According to this account, his father said Timothy "spiraled down" and became an alcoholic after he lost the role of [[Woody Boyd]] to [[Woody Harrelson]] in the sitcom ''[[Cheers]]''.{{cite news|author=Blank, Ed|url=http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/s_369501.html|title=Film Questions Man's Life Amid Wildlife|work=[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]|location=[Pittsburgh, PA]|date=September 1, 2005|accessdate=April 2012}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} Treadwell studied [[grizzly bear]]s during summer seasons for 13 years, before being killed by one of them. According to his book, ''Among Grizzlies: Living with Wild Bears in Alaska'', his mission to protect bears began in the late 1980s after surviving a near fatal [[heroin overdose]]. He claims in his book that his [[drug addiction]] grew from his [[alcoholism]].{{cn|date=September 2018}} A lover of animals since he was a child, Treadwell traveled to [[Alaska]] to watch bears after a close friend convinced him to do so. He wrote that after his first encounter with a wild bear, he knew he had found his calling in life, and that now his destiny was entwined with that of the bears. He attributed his recovery from drug and alcohol addictions entirely to his relationship with bears.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} ==Alaskan expeditions== [[File:Timothy Treadwell's last camp - cascading maps.gif|thumb|From Grizzly Sanctuary to Grizzly Maze]] Treadwell spent the early part of each season camping on the "Big Green", an open area of bear grass in [[Hallo Bay]] on the Katmai Coast. He called the area "The Grizzly Sanctuary". Treadwell was known for getting extremely close to the bears he observed, sometimes even touching them and playing with bear cubs. However, in his book, he claimed that he was always careful with the bears and actually developed a sense of mutual trust and respect with the animals. He habitually named the bears he encountered and consistently saw many of the same bears each summer, and thus claimed to build a standing relationship with them.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} In contrast, Tom Smith, a research ecologist with the Alaska Science Center of the U.S. Geological Service declared that Treadwell "...was breaking every park rule that there was, in terms of distance to the bears, harassing wildlife and interfering with natural processes. Right off the bat, his personal mission was at odds with the park service. He had been warned repeatedly." Referring to Treadwell's death, Smith concluded "It's a tragic thing, but it's not unpredictable."[http://articles.latimes.com/2003/oct/08/local/me-bear8] During the later part of each summer he would move to Kaflia Bay and camp in an area of especially thick brush he called the "Grizzly Maze". Here the chances of crossing paths with grizzlies were much higher, since the location intersected bear trails. Treadwell recorded almost 100 hours of video footage (some of which was later used to create the documentary ''Grizzly Man'') and produced a large collection of still photographs.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} Treadwell claimed to be alone with the wildlife on several occasions in his videos. However, his girlfriend Amie was with him during parts of the last three summers (the documentary says two summers) and at the time of his death. Other people possibly accompanied Treadwell during the other summer trips.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} By 2001, Treadwell became sufficiently notable to receive extensive media attention both on television and in environmental circles, and he made frequent public appearances as an environmental activist. He traveled throughout the United States to educate school children about bears and appeared on the [[Discovery Channel]], the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]],'' and ''[[Dateline NBC]]'' to discuss his experiences. He also co-authored ''Among Grizzlies: Living with Wild Bears in Alaska'' with Jewel Palovak (his co-worker with whom he lived for 20 years),{{cite web | last=Davis | first = Robert | title= Werner Herzog: The Tests and Trials of Men| work= [[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|date=April 11, 2007 | url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2007/04/werner-herzog.html| accessdate= November 5, 2014}} which describes Treadwell's adventures on the [[Alaska Peninsula]]. Treadwell and Palovak founded Grizzly People, an organization devoted to protecting bears and preserving their wilderness habitat.[http://www.grizzlypeople.com/ Grizzly People] [[Charlie Russell (Bear researcher)|Charlie Russell]], who studied bears, raised them, and lived with them in [[Kamchatka]], Russia, for a decade, worked with Treadwell. Russell wrote a lengthy critique of Treadwell's lack of basic safety precautions, such as [[pepper spray]] and [[electric fence]]s. He also commented on what he considered the standard reaction of Alaskans to hearing of Treadwell's death, writing, "If Timothy had spent those thirteen years killing bears and guiding others to do the same, eventually being killed by one, he would have been remembered in Alaska with great admiration." Russell was also critical of the film ''Grizzly Man'', saying it was inaccurate, and if Palovak "really was a protector of bears, she should have looked for a filmmaker who would have been sympathetic towards them."{{cite web|author=[[Russell, Charlie]] |date=February 21, 2006|url=http://cloudline.org/treadwell.html |title=Letters from Charlie|website=cloudline.org}} According to the organization Treadwell founded, Grizzly People, five bears were poached in the year following his death, while none had been poached while he was present in Katmai. However, according to court records as reported by the ''Anchorage Daily News'', the guilty parties were charged with poaching wildlife along Funnel Creek in the Preserve, an area open to hunting that borders the National Park. According to several sources, including Nick Jans' book, ''The Grizzly Maze'',{{cite book|author=Jans, Nick|title=The Grizzly Maze: Timothy Treadwell's Fatal Obsession with Alaskan Bears|location= New York, N.Y.|publisher= Penguin Group|date= 2005|isbn= 0-525-94886-4}} Treadwell camped only near the Katmai Coast, mainly in areas around Hallo Bay and Kaflia Bay, and never in or near the Preserve. The only effective way to patrol all {{convert|6000|sqmi|km2|-3}} of Katmai National Park is by airplane, the method used by authorities. == Conflicts with the National Park Service == Treadwell's years with the grizzlies were not without disruption. Almost from the start, the [[National Park Service]] expressed their worries about his behavior. The Park's restrictions made him increasingly irate. According to the file kept on Treadwell by the Park Service, rangers reported he had at least six violations from 1994 to 2003. Included among these violations were guiding tourists without a license, camping in the same area longer than the Park Service's seven-day limit, improper food storage, wildlife harassment, and conflicts with visitors and their guides. Treadwell also frustrated authorities by refusing to install an electric fence around his camp and refusing to carry [[bear spray]] to use as a deterrent. In fact, Treadwell had carried pepper spray with him and had resorted to using it at least one time, but wrote that he had felt terrible grief over the pain he perceived it had caused the bear and refused to use it on subsequent occasions.{{cite book|author=Treadwell, Timothy|title= Among Grizzlies: Living With Wild Bears In Alaska|publisher= Harper Collins Publishing|location= New York, New York|date= 1997}} In 1998, park rangers issued Treadwell a citation for storing an ice chest filled with food in his tent. A separate incident involved rangers ordering him to remove a prohibited portable [[Electrical generator|generator]]. When the [[National Park Service|Park Service]] imposed a new rule—often referred to as the "Treadwell Rule"—requiring all campers to move their camps at least one mile (1.6 km) every seven days, Treadwell initially obeyed the order by using a small motorboat to move his camp up and down the coast. Finding this method impractical, he later hid his camp from the Park Service in stands of trees with heavy brush. He was cited at least once for this violation.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} == Death == In October 2003, Treadwell and his girlfriend, [[physician assistant]] Amie Huguenard (born October 23, 1965, in [[Buffalo, New York]]), visited [[Katmai National Park and Preserve|Katmai National Park]], which is on the [[Alaska Peninsula]] across [[Shelikof Strait]] from [[Kodiak Island]]. In ''Grizzly Man'', [[Werner Herzog]] states that according to Treadwell's diaries, Huguenard feared bears and felt deeply uncomfortable in their presence. Her final journal entries indicated that she wanted to be away from Katmai.{{cite web | last=Medred | first = Craig | title= Woman who died with 'bear guru' was duped| work= Anchorage Daily News|date=February 18, 2005 | url=http://www.wolfsongnews.org/news/Alaska_current_events_1068.htm| accessdate= November 5, 2014}} Treadwell chose to set his campsite near a salmon stream where grizzlies commonly feed in autumn. Treadwell was in the park later in the year than usual, at a time when bears attempt to gain as much fat as possible before winter. Food was scarce that fall, causing the grizzly bears to be even more aggressive than usual.{{cite book | last = Jans | first = Nick | title = The Grizzly Obsession | publisher = Dutton Adult | location = City | year = 2005 | isbn = 0-525-94886-4 }} Treadwell was to leave the park at his usual time of year but extended his stay a week in an effort to locate a favorite female brown bear. He said he hated modern civilization and felt better in nature with the bears than he did in big cities around humans. The bears he had been used to during the summer had already gone into [[hibernation]], and bears that Treadwell did not know from other parts of the park were moving into the area. Some of the last footage taken by Treadwell, hours before his death, includes video of a bear diving into the river repeatedly for a piece of dead salmon. Treadwell mentioned in the footage that he did not feel entirely comfortable around that particular bear. In ''Grizzly Man'', Herzog posits that Treadwell may have filmed the very bear that killed him. [[File:Treadwell Incident Map.jpg|right|thumb|Diagram of attack site showing positions of bodies. Longitude incorrectly marked as East rather than West. {{coord|58|14|50.63|N|154|15|24.68|W|region:US-AK_type:event}}]]Around noon on Sunday, October 5, 2003, Treadwell spoke with an associate in [[Malibu, California]], by [[satellite phone]]; Treadwell mentioned no problems with any bears. The next day, October 6, Willy Fulton, a Kodiak [[air taxi]] pilot, arrived at Treadwell and Huguenard's campsite to pick them up but found the area abandoned, except for a bear, and contacted the local park rangers. The couple's mangled remains were discovered quickly upon investigation. Treadwell's disfigured head, partial spine, and right forearm and hand, with his wristwatch still on, were recovered a short distance from the camp. Huguenard's partial remains were found next to the torn and collapsed tents, partially buried in a mound of twigs and dirt. A large male grizzly (tagged Bear 141) protecting the campsite was killed by park rangers during their attempt to retrieve the bodies. A second adolescent bear was also killed a short time later, when it charged the park rangers. An on-site [[necropsy]] of Bear 141 revealed human body parts such as fingers and limbs. The younger bear was consumed by other animals before it could be necropsied.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} In the 85-year history of Katmai National Park, this was the first known incident of a person being killed by a bear.{{cite web | last=Sanders | first = Kevin | title= Night of the Grizzly, A True Story Of Love And Death In The Wilderness | work=Yellowstone Outdoor Adventures |year=2006 | url=http://www.yellowstone-bearman.com/Tim_Treadwell.html | accessdate= February 3, 2011}} A [[video camera]] was recovered at the site that proved to have been operating during the attack, but police said that the six-minute tape contained only voices and cries as a brown bear mauled Treadwell to death. The tape begins with Treadwell yelling that he is being attacked. "Come out here; I'm being killed out here," he screams. {{cite web|date=October 10, 2003|title=Final cries of couple killed by bear|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/1443788/Final-cries-of-couple-killed-by-bear.html|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|accessdate=November 5, 2014}} That the tape contained only sound led troopers to believe the attack might have happened while the camera was stuffed in a duffel bag or during the dark of night. In ''Grizzly Man'', filmmaker Herzog claims that the lens cap of the camera was left on, suggesting that Treadwell and Huguenard were in the process of setting up for another video sequence when the attack happened. The camera had been turned on just before the attack, presumably by sound activation, but the camera recorded only six minutes of audio before running out of tape. This, however, was enough time to record the bear's initial attack on Treadwell and his agonized screams, its retreat after Huguenard tells Treadwell to play dead and when she attacked it and its return to carry Treadwell off into the forest. == Media attention == * ''[[Grizzly Man]]'' (2005), directed by [[Werner Herzog]], is a documentary about Treadwell's work with wildlife in Alaska. Released theatrically by Lions Gate Films, it later was telecast on the [[Discovery Channel]]. Treadwell's own footage is featured, along with interviews with people who knew him. Although Herzog praises Treadwell's video footage and photographs, he states his belief that Treadwell was a disturbed individual with a [[death drive|death wish]]. Treadwell's [[anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] treatment of wild animals is apparent in the documentary. * ''The Grizzly Man Diaries'' is an eight-episode [[mini-series]] that premiered on August 22, 2008, on [[Animal Planet]] and is a [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of ''Grizzly Man''. Produced by Creative Differences, the series chronicles the last 10 years of Treadwell's life with diary entries, and footage and photographs taken by Treadwell during his expeditions. == See also == * [[Bear attack]] * [[List of fatal bear attacks in North America]] * [[Lillian Alling]] * [[Christopher McCandless]], subject of [[Jon Krakauer]]’s book ''[[Into the Wild (book)|Into the Wild]]'' (1996), later adapted as a [[Into the Wild (film)|2007 film]] directed by [[Sean Penn]] * [[Carl McCunn]], wildlife photographer who became stranded in the Alaskan wilderness and eventually committed suicide when he ran out of supplies (1981) * [[Lars Monsen]], Norwegian adventurer and TV personality who once traveled by foot, canoe, and dog sled from the east coast of Canada to the west coast, a project which took over two years to complete * [[Richard Proenneke]], who survived in the Alaskan wilderness for 30 years * [[Everett Ruess]], who disappeared in the Utah wilderness in 1934 * [[Sankebetsu brown bear incident]] (1915), the worst bear attack in Japanese history, in which seven people were killed * [[Ed Wardle]], who documented his solo wilderness adventure in the 2009 television series ''Alone in the Wild'' * [[Backcountry (film)]], film based upon a real life story. == References == {{Reflist|1}} ==Further reading== * Conesa-Sevilla, J. (2008). Walking With Bears: An Ecopsychological Study of Timothy (Dexter) Treadwell.''The Trumpeter'', 24, 1, 136-150. * Dewberry, Eric; Conceiving Grizzly Man through the "Powers of the False"; 2008 * [http://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/Grizzly-mauls-kills-a-bear-expert-1126392.php Associated Press: Grizzly mauls, kills a bear 'expert' Alaska attack also takes life of female companion in park]: 2003 * Lapinski, Mike. ''Death in the Grizzly Maze: The Timothy Treadwell Story''. Falcon, 2005. {{ISBN|0-7627-3677-1}} * Treadwell, Timothy and Palovak, Jewel. ''Among Grizzlies: Living With Wild Bears in Alaska''. HarperCollins, 1997. {{ISBN|0-06-017393-9}} == External links == * [http://grizzlypeople.com/ Grizzly People], founded by Treadwell to preserve bears and their habitat * {{IMDb name|1765842}} * [http://animal.discovery.com/tv/grizzly-man-diaries/timothy-treadwell/timothy-treadwell.html Timothy Treadwell's Biography] * [http://animal.discovery.com/tv/grizzly-man-diaries/journals/journals.html Timothy Treadwell's Journals] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080915202430/http://animal.discovery.com/tv/grizzly-man-diaries/pictures/pictures.html Timothy Treadwell's Wildlife Photography] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090815072552/http://www.adn.com/news/alaska/treadwell/story/43465.html "Wildlife author killed, eaten by bears he loved"] at ''Anchorage Daily News'', October 8, 2003 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100129013139/http://www.adn.com/news/alaska/treadwell/story/585763.html "Treadwell: 'Get out here. I'm getting killed'"] at ''Anchorage Daily News'', October 9, 2003 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090921012744/http://www.adn.com/news/alaska/treadwell/story/585893.html "Biologist believes errors led to attack"] at ''Anchorage Daily News'', October 10, 2003 * [http://www.katmaibears.com/timothytreadwell.htm The Myth of Timothy Treadwell] at ''Coastal Bears of Katmai National Park'': First-hand account of encounters with Timothy Treadwell in Katmai, by John Rogers * {{Find a Grave|13248861}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Treadwell, Timothy}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:2003 deaths]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Alaska]] [[Category:American environmentalists]] [[Category:American documentary filmmakers]] [[Category:American nomads]] [[Category:Deaths due to animal attacks in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths due to bear attacks]] [[Category:People from Long Island]] [[Category:People with bipolar disorder]] [[Category:Filmed accidental deaths]] [[Category:Unusual deaths]]

{{for|the Australian rugby league footballer|Trevor Bailey (rugby league)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use British English|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox cricketer | name = Trevor Bailey | fu1llname = Trevor Edward Bailey | nickname = Barnacle, The Boil | image = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1923|12|3|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Westcliff-on-Sea]], [[Essex]], England | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|2|10|1923|12|3|df=y}} | death_place = [[Westcliff-on-Sea]], Essex, England | batting = Right-handed | bowling = Right-arm [[Fast bowling|fast-medium]] | role = [[All-rounder]]
| international = true | country = England | testdebutdate = 11 June | testdebutyear = 1949 | testdebutagainst = New Zealand | testcap = 342 | lasttestdate = 13 February | lasttestyear = 1959 | lasttestagainst = Australia
| club1 = [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]] | year1 = 1946–1967 | club2 = [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC) | year2 = 1949–1964 | club3 = [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge University]] | year3 = 1947–1948
| columns = 3 | column1 = [[Test cricket|Test]] | matches1 = 61 | runs1 = 2,290 | bat avg1 = 29.74 | 100s/50s1 = 1/10 | top score1 = 134[[not out|*]] | deliveries1 = 9,712 | wickets1 = 132 | bowl avg1 = 29.21 | fivefor1 = 5 | tenfor1 = 1 | best bowling1 = 7/34 | catches/stumpings1 = 32/0 | column2 = [[First-class cricket|First-class]] | matches2 = 682 | runs2 = 28,641 | bat avg2 = 33.42 | 100s/50s2 = 28/150 | top score2 = 205 | deliveries2 = 116,665 | wickets2 = 2,082 | bowl avg2 = 23.13 | fivefor2 = 110 | tenfor2 = 13 | best bowling2 = 10/90 | catches/stumpings2 = 426/0 | column3 = [[List A cricket|List A]] | matches3 = 7 | runs3 = 93 | bat avg3 = 15.50 | 100s/50s3 = 0/0 | top score3 = 38 | deliveries3 = 504 | wickets3 = 11 | bowl avg3 = 26.36 | fivefor3 = 0 | tenfor3 = 0 | best bowling3 = 4/37 | catches/stumpings3 = 3/0
| date = 14 December | year = 2008 | source = http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Players/0/853/853.html CricketArchive }} '''Trevor Edward Bailey''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE}} (3 December 1923 – 10 February 2011)<ref name="obit">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11573997 |publisher=BBC News |title=Obituary: Trevor Bailey |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/story/500211.html|title=Trevor Bailey dies at age of 87|date=10 February 2011|publisher=espncricinfo|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> was an [[England cricket team|England]] [[Test cricket|Test]] [[cricket]]er, cricket writer and broadcaster.
An [[all-rounder]], Bailey was known for his skilful but unspectacular batting. As the BBC reflected in his obituary: "His stubborn refusal to be out normally brought more pleasure to the team than to the spectators."<ref name="obit"/> This defensive style of play brought him the first of his nicknames, "Barnacle Bailey",<ref name="teleg">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/sport-obituaries/8316020/Trevor-Bailey.html# |title=Trevor Bailey |publisher=Telegraph |date= 10 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-10 |location=London}}</ref> but he was a good enough cricketer that he has retrospectively been calculated to have been the leading all-rounder in the world for most of his international career.
In later life, Bailey wrote a number of books and commentated on the game. He was particularly known for the 26 years he spent working for the [[BBC]] on the [[Test Match Special]] radio programme.
==Early life== Bailey was born in [[Westcliff-on-Sea]], [[Essex]]. His father was a civil servant in the [[Admiralty]]. Bailey grew up in modest affluence: "The family lived in [a]<!-- Telegraph omits this word --> semi-detached house at Leigh-on-Sea, complete with a live-in maid on 12 shillings (60p) a week; they did not, however, own a car."<ref name="teleg"/> He first learned to play cricket on the beach.<ref name="teleg"/>
He won sporting scholarships to attend [[Alleyn Court Prep School]], where he learned cricket from former [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]] captain [[Denys Wilcox]],<ref name="teleg"/> and then [[Dulwich College]].<ref name=guardian>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2011/feb/10/trevor-bailey-england-barnacle | location=London |work=The Guardian | first=Andy | last=Bull | title=Trevor Bailey: England legend and all-rounder in more than one sense | date=11 February 2011}}</ref> In his first year, aged just 14, he was selected for Dulwich's [[First XI]] cricket team.<ref name="obit"/> He came top of the school's [[batting average|batting]] and [[bowling average]]s in 1939 and 1940, became captain in 1941, and was top of the averages again in his last year at Dulwich, 1942.<ref name="teleg"/>
He was commissioned as a [[second lieutenant]] in the [[Royal Marines]] after leaving school;<ref name="modelling">http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/493308.html</ref> he was "not enamoured of war, and won some reputation as defending counsel in court martials". Though [[World War II]] was still in progress, he received an early discharge in January 1945 to return to Alleyn Court Prep School as a schoolmaster. He subsequently attended [[St John's College, Cambridge]] for two years, reading English and History and graduating in 1948.<ref name="teleg"/> He won [[Blue (university sport)#University of Cambridge|Blues]] for both cricket and football both years, 1947 and 1948.<ref name="obit"/> The Cambridge football team included [[Doug Insole]], whom Bailey would later succeed as captain of Essex County Cricket Club.
==Career==
===Cricket=== Bailey made his [[First-class cricket|first-class]] cricket debut in September 1945, aged 22, for the "Under 33s" [[scratch team]], in a match at [[Lord's]], against an "Over 33s" team, and made his debut playing [[county cricket]] for Essex in May 1946.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/0/853/First-Class_Matches.html |title=The Home of CricketArchive |publisher=Cricketarchive.com |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> He quickly became a lynchpin of the Essex team, and made his Test debut for England against [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]] at [[Headingley Cricket Ground|Headingley]] in [[New Zealand cricket team in England in 1949|June 1949]], taking 6 wickets for 118 runs in his first match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62700.html |title=1st Test: England v New Zealand at Leeds, Jun 11–14, 1949 | Cricket Scorecard |publisher=ESPN Cricinfo |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
A right-arm [[fast bowler|fast-medium bowler]], dependable right-handed [[batsman]] and strong [[Fielding (cricket)|fielder]], often in the [[slip (cricket)|slips]] or at leg gully, Bailey played 61 Tests for England between 1949 and 1959. His [[swing bowling]] provided an effective foil for the fast bowling of [[Alec Bedser]], and later [[Fred Trueman]], [[Brian Statham]] and [[Frank Tyson]]. He is described as having had "a model high, sideways-on action which encouraged outswing. At his best he could touch greatness..."<ref name="teleg"/> He took 132 wickets at the [[bowling average]] of 29, scored a century (134 not out) in attaining a useful [[batting average]] of nearly 30, and took 32 catches.
He is best remembered for his obdurate defensive batting, especially in matches against Australia. England were facing defeat by the Australians at Lord's in the [[Australian cricket team in England in 1953|Second Test in 1953]]. Bailey shared a defensive fifth wicket stand with [[Willie Watson (England cricketer)|Willie Watson]], defying the bowlers for over four hours to earn a draw, taking 257 minutes to score 71 runs.<ref name="gobit">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2011/feb/10/trevor-bailey-obituary | location=London |work=The Guardian | first=David | last=Foot | title=Trevor Bailey obituary | date=10 February 2011}}</ref> In the fourth Test of that series, at [[Headingley Cricket Ground|Headingley]], Bailey again played an important part in ensuring that England avoided going 1–0 down, which would have ended their hopes of regaining [[the Ashes]]. When the last day began England were 177–5 in their second innings, only 78 runs ahead. Bailey scored 38 in 262 minutes, and Australia eventually had to score 177 in only 115 minutes. They reached a point where they needed only another 66 in 45 minutes with seven wickets left. But Bailey went back to his long run and slowed the over rate, as well as bowling negatively wide of the leg stump, and Australia fell 30 runs short and the game was drawn.<ref>[[Ralph Barker]] & [[Irving Rosenwater]], ''England v Australia: A compendium of Test cricket between the countries 1877–1968'', Batsford, 1969, {{ISBN|0-7134-0317-9}}, p 220.</ref> England went on to win the fifth and final Test and so regained [[the Ashes]].
His best Test bowling figures of 7/34, bowling [[outswing]] on a flat pitch, enabled England to bowl out the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] for 139 in the first innings of the fifth Test at [[Kingston, Jamaica]], in [[English cricket team in West Indies in 1953–54|1953–54]], on a pitch on which the groundsman expected the home side to score 700.<ref name="teleg"/> This enabled England to win the match and to share the series 2–2.<ref>[http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/139867.html The second-most controversial tour in history]</ref> He was vice-captain on that tour, and may be considered unlucky never to have been appointed captain of England. According to [[Alan Gibson]]: "It is astonishing that so good a cricketer, so thoughtful a judge, and so friendly a man, should have been passed over." However, he adds: "He is, or was in his earlier days, a man of contradictions, who sometimes enjoyed being irritating, to his captain, to his colleagues, to the public, but most of all to his opponents."<ref>{{Cite book|last = Gibson|first = Alan|title = The Cricket Captains of England|publisher = Cassell|year = 1979|location= London|isbn = 0-304-29779-8|page=194}}</ref>
He played his final Tests in [[the Ashes]] [[English cricket team in Australia in 1958–59|tour to Australia in 1958–59]]. He had a bad tour, during which he scored the slowest half-century in first-class cricket, reaching 50 just 3 minutes short of 6 hours at the crease,<ref name="teleg"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/284093.html |title=Records/Test matches/Batting records: Slowest Fifties |publisher=Stats.espncricinfo.com |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> in England's second innings during the 1st Test at Brisbane.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62850.html |title=1st Test: Australia v England at Brisbane, Dec 5–10, 1958 | Cricket Scorecard |publisher=ESPN Cricinfo |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> This was the first Test match to be broadcast on television in Australia.<ref name="ft"/> He bagged a pair in his final test, the last of the tour at Melbourne,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62854.html |title=5th Test: Australia v England at Melbourne, Feb 13–18, 1959 | Cricket Scorecard |publisher=ESPN Cricinfo |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> He was never selected for England's Test side again, but continued to play first-class cricket for Essex for another 8 years, and in the 1959 season became the only player since the Second World War to score more than 2,000 runs and take 100 wickets in a single domestic season.
His [[first-class cricket]] career began just after World War II in 1946 and lasted 21 years as he played 682 matches, taking 2,082 wickets at a bowling average of 23.13, which puts him 25th on the all-time list of wicket-takers. Bailey achieved the rare feat of taking all 10 wickets in an innings, for 90 runs, against [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] at [[Clacton]] in 1949. His 28,641 runs in [[first-class cricket]] put him 67th on the all-time list of run-scorers. He captained the county from 1961 to 1966. He was also the county's secretary (i.e. the chief administrative officer) from 1964 to 1969, having previously had a spell as assistant secretary. He arranged for [[Warwickshire County Cricket Club|Warwickshire]] to make an interest-free loan to Essex in 1965 which allowed Essex to buy its [[County Cricket Ground, Chelmsford|Chelmsford ground]].<ref name="modelling"/> This enabled him to receive a salary whilst at the same time technically remaining an [[History of English amateur cricket|amateur]] cricketer, although he was better paid than the club's professionals. However, [[Keith Fletcher]], a playing colleague at Essex, did not begrudge him his salary, saying: "...he was a better cricketer than the pros and someone instrumental in taking Essex County Cricket Club into the modern era. He was cricket and Essex, through and through.".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/england/8317128/Trevor-Bailey-is-remembered-for-his-obdurate-batting-and-as-one-of-Englands-finest-all-rounders.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Derek | last=Pringle | title=Trevor Bailey is remembered for his obdurate batting and as one of England's finest all-rounders | date=10 February 2011}}</ref> He supplemented his income by undertaking advertising work while playing for Essex, modelling for [[Brylcreem]], [[Shredded Wheat]] and [[Lucozade]].<ref name="modelling"/>
===Football=== He played [[association football|football]] for [[Cambridge University A.F.C.|Cambridge University]] (appearing in the University Match against [[Oxford University|Oxford]]), [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] reserves, [[Clapton F.C.|Clapton]], [[Leytonstone F.C.|Leytonstone]] and [[Walthamstow Avenue F.C.|Walthamstow Avenue]]. At various times he played at [[centre-half]], [[inside-right]] and on the [[Wide midfielder|wing]]. He was a member of the Walthamstow Avenue side which won the [[FA Amateur Cup]] in 1951-2, winning the final before a Wembley crowd of 100,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisistotalessex.co.uk/news/ESSEX-Cricket-legend-Trevor-Bailey-dies/article-3209162-detail/article.html |title=CRICKETING legend Trevor Bailey, 87, died in the early hours this morning (Thursday Feb 10) at a flat fire at a retirement complex |publisher=Thisistotalessex.co.uk |date=14 December 2010 |accessdate=2011-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130505064957/http://www.thisistotalessex.co.uk/news/ESSEX-Cricket-legend-Trevor-Bailey-dies/article-3209162-detail/article.html |archivedate=5 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The following season, he played in the side which reached the fourth round of the [[FA Cup]]. Drawn against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at [[Old Trafford]], they drew 1–1, a fine achievement for an amateur side. The replay took place at [[Highbury Stadium|Highbury]], and Manchester United won 5–2.<ref>Trevor Bailey, ''Wickets, Catches and the Odd Run'', Willow Books, 1986, {{ISBN|0-00-218127-4}}, pp197-207.</ref> He later became a director of [[Southend United F.C.]].<ref name=indy>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/trevor-bailey-combative-and-uncompromising-cricketer-hailed-as-the-worlds-best-allrounder-in-the-1950s-2211183.html | location=London |work=The Independent | title=Trevor Bailey: Combative and uncompromising cricketer hailed as the world's best all-rounder in the 1950s | date=11 February 2011}}</ref>
==Writer and broadcaster== After retiring from cricket in 1967, Bailey continued to play for Westcliff-on-Sea Cricket Club for many years and also became a cricket journalist and broadcaster. He was the cricket and football correspondent of the ''[[Financial Times]]'' for 23 years.<ref name="ft">http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/965de652-35ca-11e0-b67c-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1E3O6fqJZ</ref><ref>[http://www.dulwich.org.uk/OA_Document_1.aspx?id=1:29463&id=1:29454&id=1:29431 Biography on Dulwich College website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519215043/http://www.dulwich.org.uk/OA_Document_1.aspx?id=1%3A29463&id=1%3A29454&id=1%3A29431 |date=19 May 2011 }}</ref> He was a regular on the [[BBC]]'s [[Test Match Special]] from 1974 to 1999,<ref name="reflect">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/england/9393503.stm |publisher=BBC Sport|title=Cricket – Cricket mourns England Test great Trevor Bailey |date= 10 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> where fellow commentator [[Brian Johnston]] nicknamed him '''The Boil''', based on the supposed Australian barrackers' pronunciation of his name as "Boiley". (The ''Daily Telegraph'' gives an alternative source for this nickname from the pronunciation of his surname by the [[East End]] supporters of the Walthamstow Avenue football team.<ref name="teleg"/>) During his retirement he would watch Westcliff-on-Sea Cricket Club play at their [[Chalkwell Park]] Ground where he had played many times for school, club and county.<ref>[http://www.suttonelms.org.uk/tms.html#y TMS personalities]</ref>
He was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in the [[1994 Birthday Honours]] for services to cricket.<ref> {{London Gazette |date=10 June 1994 |supp=y |issue=53696 |page=8 }}</ref>
==Legacy== He remains the only player since the [[Second World War]] to score more than 2,000 runs in a season and take 100 wickets, a feat he achieved in 1959, and he achieved the all-rounders' double of 1,000 [[run (cricket)|runs]] and 100 wickets in a season eight times, a post-World War II record he shares with [[Fred Titmus]]. He was selected as one of the five [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] in 1950. He is also one of three players (the others are [[Fred Titmus]] and [[Ray Illingworth]]) to have scored 20,000 first-class runs and taken 2,000 wickets since the [[Second World War]].<ref name="teleg"/> According to the retrospectively calculated [[ICC cricket ratings]], for most of his career, Bailey was the best all-rounder in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.relianceiccrankings.com/playerdisplay/test/all-rounder/?id=117&graph=ranking |title=Reliance ICC Test Championship All-Rounder Rankings – Trevor Bailey |work=[[Reliance ICC Player Rankings]] |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> In the individual disciplines, his bowling saw him achieve the higher ranking, as high as eighth in the [[1957 English cricket season|summer of 1957]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.relianceiccrankings.com/playerdisplay/test/bowling/?id=117&graph=ranking |title=Reliance ICC Test Championship Bowling Rankings – Trevor Bailey |publisher=Relianceiccrankings.com |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
[[Doug Insole]], his one-time captain at Essex, described him thus: "Trevor was quite a stroppy lad in his early cricketing years, and a bit of a rebel. He was a very intense character – we used to tease him about that in the dressing room, and he did mellow over the years."<ref name="briggs">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/8319693/Warrior-Trevor-Bailey-cared-little-for-entertainment.html "Warrior Trevor Bailey cared little for entertainment" from ''Daily Telegraph''] Retrieved 13 February 2011.</ref>
Simon Briggs wrote: "There was little comfy or cosy about his cricket career. Rather, he fitted into a long tradition of hard-nosed English pragmatists – a lineage that runs from [[WG Grace]], through [[Douglas Jardine|Jardine]] and up to [[Nasser Hussain]]... To Bailey and company, the best way to honour the gods of cricket was to commit your heart and soul to the fight. For them, a Test match was a contest between two groups of warriors. Its entertainment value was almost irrelevant."<ref name="briggs"/>
He was renowned for his slow scoring in Tests against Australia, [[Neville Cardus]] writing of one innings in his book ''Full Score'' (1970, chapter "Cricket of Vintage"): "Before he gathered together 20 runs, a newly-married couple could have left [[Heathrow]] and arrived in [[Lisbon]], there to enjoy a honeymoon. By the time Bailey had congealed 50, this happily wedded pair could easily have settled down in a semi-detached house in [[Surbiton]]; and by the time his innings had gone to its close they conceivably might have been divorced."<ref>{{cite book|last=Cardus|first=Neville|authorlink=Neville Cardus|title=Full Score|url=http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/MISC/HUMOUR/CARDUS_ON_BAILEY_1959|accessdate=September 2013|year=1970|publisher=[[Cassell (publisher)|Cassell]]|location=London |chapter=Cricket of Vintage| isbn= 030493643X}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Various|first=|title=The Authors XI: A Season of English Cricket from Hackney to Hambledon|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gALUQJaS6fMC&pg=PT35&lpg=PT35&dq=%22Before+he+gathered+together+20+runs,+a+newly-married+couple+could+have+left+Heathrow+and+arrived+in+Lisbon&source=bl&ots=uEO0V2qfoZ&sig=aA0wUKIXFVZTyP3maUCHD9Hl2lI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=GsgyUszlD4bJiAebsIHACQ&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22Before%20he%20gathered%20together%2020%20runs%2C%20a%20newly-married%20couple%20could%20have%20left%20Heathrow%20and%20arrived%20in%20Lisbon&f=false |chapter=Cricket and Broadcasting (Jon Hotten)|accessdate=September 2013|date=Jun 6, 2013|publisher=[[Google eBook]] / [[A&C Black]]|isbn=1408840464}}</ref> He was nicknamed "Barnacle" for his implacable defensive batting.<ref>{{cricinfo|ref=ci/content/player/8944.html}}</ref>
In Cardus's piece on him in ''Close of Play'', first published in 1956, he was more complimentary: "Some cricketers are born to greatness. Bailey achieved it... He conquers by tremendous effort... Yet Bailey... loves to attack any bowler... He has made catches bordering on the marvellous... It is no small thing to be a Trevor Bailey in a world of anonymous mediocrity."<ref>Neville Cardus, ''Close of Play'', Sportsmans Book Club, 1957, pp64-66.</ref>
Bailey died in a fire in his retirement flat in [[Westcliff-on-Sea]] on 10 February 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southendstandard.co.uk/news/echo/8844541.Updated__Cricketing_legend_dies_in_flat_fire/ |title=Updated: Cricketing legend dies in flat fire |work=[[Southend Standard]] |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-essex-12414599 |publisher=BBC News |title=Former England cricketer Trevor Bailey dies in fire |date= 10 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> His wife, Greta, survived.<ref name="teleg"/> They had two sons and one daughter.<ref name="gobit"/><ref name=indy/>
The chairman of the [[England and Wales Cricket Board]], [[Giles Clarke]], described him as "one of the finest all-rounders this country has ever produced", while [[Jonathan Agnew]], who worked with Bailey on Test Match Special, wrote of him: "dogged batsman, aggressive bowler. Intelligent cricketer. Wonderfully concise pundit. Great sense of humour."<ref name="reflect"/>
==Bibliography== He wrote the following books:
*''Cricketers in the Making'', with D R Wilcox, Hutchinson *''Playing to Win'', Hutchinson, 1954 - an account of the 1953 Test series in which England regained the Ashes which had been held by Australia since 1934 *''Trevor Bailey's Cricket Book'', Muller, 1959 *''Championship Cricket'', Muller, 1961 *''Improve Your Cricket'', Penguin, 1963 *''The Greatest of My Time'', Sportsmans, 1970 *''Sir Gary: Life of Sir Garfield Sobers'', Collins, 1976, {{ISBN|978-0-00-216764-2}} *''History of Cricket'', Allen & Unwin, 1979, {{ISBN|978-0-04-796049-9}} *''Lord's Taverners' Fifty Greatest, 1945–83'', Heinemann, 1983, {{ISBN|978-0-434-98039-0}} *''From Larwood to Lillee'', with [[Fred Trueman]], Macdonald, 1984, {{ISBN|978-0-356-10412-6}} *''Wickets, Catches and the Odd Run'' (autobiography), Willow Books, 1986, {{ISBN|0-00-218127-4}} *''Spinners' Web'', with [[Fred Trueman]], Willow Books, 1988, {{ISBN|978-0-00-218267-6}}
Alan Hill has written a biography:
*Alan Hill, ''The Valiant Cricketer: The Biography of Trevor Bailey'', Pitch Publishing Ltd, 2012, {{ISBN|978-1908051868}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * [http://www.britishpathe.com/workspace.php?id=10639 Trevor Bailey newsreel archive]
